Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Intra-regional agreements, migrants, and the state

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project analyzes the process that led to the national implementation of Residency Agreements among nations affiliated with Mercosur. Mercosur is a regional trade agreement among developing countries in South America that is designed to resolve unauthorized migration in a manner that protects the rights of immigrants without compromising national security. Beginning in 2002 nationals of the affiliated countries could relocate, obtain legal residency, and access civil, economic, cultural, and social rights. By 2014, nine out of twelve South American countries had affiliated with Mercosur and included the Residency Agreements in their national migration policy. The widespread adaptation of this policy suggests that policymakers had to build support for these agreements from government officials and migrant advocates within six countries: Argentina, Bolivia, Brazil, Chile, Paraguay, and Uruguay. This project analyzes the process that led to the national implementation of the agreements in these six countries to identify the actors and factors that facilitated or hindered the agreement's adaptation as national legislation. This project expands our understanding of how regional migration policy can serve as a tool to reform national immigration law. This project will also identify new models and strategies for addressing unauthorized migration that can inform policymakers and advocates around the world.

Specifically, this project analyzes the impact of Mercosur regionalism in the six countries that negotiated and first adapted the Residency Agreements. Using comparative historical methods, this project identifies the international forces, regional contexts, and the domestic legal, political, and economic factors that facilitated or hindered the passage of the Residency Agreements at the national level. It also identifies the key actors and the policy networks shaping this regional to national policy change. The Co-Principal Investigator conducted N=112 interviews, created a regional and national migration policy database, and compiled an economic growth and trade indicators database. Overall, this research bridges international migration and regionalism literatures and identifies new processes that reform immigration law. This project contributes to the theory by specifying how regional migration policy is a determinant of national immigration policy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In the last 20 years, South American governments have responded to increases in undocumented immigration from neighboring countries by passing immigration policies that facilitate access to legalization and rights. Scholars argue that the Mercosur Residency Agreements (2002), which promote the legalization and rights of undocumented immigrants were pivotal to this liberal turn. Even though Mercosur cannot enforce its regional policy at the national level, scholars are puzzled as to how Argentina, Bolivia, Brazil, Chile, Paraguay, and Uruguay adapted these agreements as national legislation by 2009. Using a structural power lens, this study explores how government and non-government actors leveraged organizational rules and practices of Mercosur and national political, legal, and political contexts to promote the Residency Agreements. Specifically, to analyze how Mercosur’s regionalism and Residency Agreements were negotiated and reshaped national policy my research draws on 124 in-depth interviews with actors involved in migration policymaking in these six countries and original databases of immigration laws and economic, migration, and trade indicators from 1970-2015. The NSF grant allowed me to pay for expert transcriptions for 103.1 hours of interview data.

I found that economic and political elites in Paraguay, a state with low infrastructural power and an agricultural economy dependent on trade, oppose the Residency Agreements for seven years because undocumented Brazilians were framed as a threat of wealthy, disloyal, and powerful colonizers. The Brazilian and Argentine delegates leveraged Mercosur’s regular meetings to address Paraguay’s opposition because their governing coalitions were committed to regional integration and to using immigration policy as an instrument to achieve this goal. Brazilian delegates responded by paying to improve the infrastructure of Paraguay’s migration department and by building a policy network with immigrant rights advocates who reframed undocumented Brazilians as vulnerable, poor and landless. Simultaneously, Argentina reshaped the migration governance status quo in the region by unilaterally implementing the Residency Agreements first and negotiating bilateral agreements to convince other South American countries to do the same. Over time, the consequences of the Paraguayan resistance incremented and Paraguayan officials eventually ratified the agreements.

Even though the agreements were ratified, I find that the legal and political context in Chile, Paraguay, and Brazil prevented the complete internalization of the Residency Agreements. Additionally, even in countries where the agreements are fully internalized (e.g., Argentina), indigenous immigrants from Bolivia remain undocumented because they had limited contact with the Bolivian state, did not have access to state-issued identification documents, retained pre-colonial norms of land and movement, and tend to migrate clandestinely. At the country of destination, these indigenous immigrants tend to remain disconnected from the state, undocumented, and unaware of their ability to access legal residency or rights.

Accordingly, this project contributes to international migration and regionalism literatures by identifying both the mechanisms through which Mercosur’s regionalism and Residency Agreements shape national immigration policies and the factors impeding their full domestic implementation.  First, this study departs from other studies that assume a collaborative and corporative diffusion of the Residency Agreements and identifies how structural power at the state and Mercosur spheres shaped the trajectory of the negotiations. These findings indicate that relative power asymmetries between developing countries are challenged and reproduced at the regional policymaking arenas of Mercosur. In turn, regional integration projects provide new opportunities for migration policy collaboration and innovation. The implications of these preliminary findings are important because there are approximately 28 regional trade agreements or trading blocs in the world and the majority are using migration policy as an instrument for regional integration. Additionally, this study also advances our understanding of the factors that shape migration policies that address south-to-south migratory flows (or migration between developing countries), which constitute 40% of all international migration. Specifically, I have identified key new factors that shape migration policy outcomes, these include: the state infrastructural power, agricultural trade elites, the relative power of the migrants’ country of origin, and regional trade agreements.

More broadly, this project is identifying more humane models for addressing undocumented migration as well as possible roadblocks and shortcomings of these models. Findings are also being used to inform academics, policymakers, and advocates around the world. For instance, findings from this study have been presented at academic conferences in Italy, Mexico, Canada, and the U.S. The Co-PI has been invited to consult Mercosur, as well as the Chilean and Uruguayan governments, and to present her findings at UCLA, Occidental College and at Grinnell College. Finally, the Co-PI has trained eight research assistants—four are in Chile, two in Brazil, one in Colombia, and one at Columbia University—on how to conduct international and comparative historical research using interviews on hard-to-reach elite policymakers. Finally, as a result of this project merits and future promise, the Co-PI has received the ISA-West Emerging Scholars Award and the Charles & Sue Young Graduate Award —the highest honor given by the UCLA Deans.
